name: Procedural Grammar Editor
impact: Designed and developed a standalone procedural building authoring system that replaced manual grammar editing with a visual, deterministic workflow. The project validated an end-to-end approach for artist-driven procedural facade creation, producing pipeline-ready data suitable for Unreal Engine–based procedural systems.
responsibilities: Solely architected and implemented a standalone desktop application for procedural building authoring using Python and Qt.
Designed an artist-facing visual grammar workflow enabling intuitive construction of complex, multi-floor building facades.
Developed real-time 2D and 3D preview systems to allow immediate validation of structural and proportional changes.
Built deterministic grammar resolution and normalization systems to ensure correct, repeatable outputs.
Designed content and asset management workflows to support reusable floor styles, module catalogs, and engine-facing data exports.
context: This project was developed as an R&D prototype in collaboration with Square Enix’s internal research group through Atlas as a design partner. The goal was to explore scalable, artist-friendly workflows for procedural building facade authoring. The system reached a fully functional, end-to-end prototype stage and successfully validated the technical and UX concepts before the initiative was later deprioritized due to internal roadmap shifts.
challenges: Procedural building grammars are traditionally authored as opaque text expressions, making them error-prone, difficult to visualize, and inaccessible to artists. Additionally, ensuring deterministic, width-accurate results across multiple floors and facades introduced significant system design and validation challenges.
solutions: I designed a visual grammar authoring tool backed by a formal, deterministic grammar resolution system. Artists interact directly with modular facade elements and structural groups, while the system maintains a canonical grammar representation and produces normalized, pipeline-ready outputs. Real-time visual feedback and structured content management ensured rapid iteration without sacrificing correctness or scalability.
